summary: Great company, suffering from big company issues
pros: Product and tech leadership are outstanding, no one else is doing what Google is and succeeding. It remains to be seen if Sundar can continue to do what Larry and Sergey did the past decade.
cons: Sales / business side is becoming political, zero sum game and bureaucratic. You spend a ton of time playing internal politics, low engagement work and have a reorg every 12 months.
advice-to-mgmt: Figure out a way to make the business side more integrated with product and keep sales teams smaller to ensure it doesn't become a political game.

pros: Work life balance is great. Free food.
cons: Free food but not great. Perks are not easy to understand.

pros: Great coworkers, detailed docs and a lot of learning materials to help you become a good engineer.
cons: 1. There is not so much work to do. 2. food is not good 3. life is just too at ease, no challenge.
advice-to-mgmt: Great manager, he is very helpful and warm to people. But some time he is a little bit lazy that he always has some excuse to leave office early or directly work from home.

pros: Free food, smart people, great pay, exciting work! The bay area has beautiful weather as well which is a bonus
cons: It is hard to advance up the mangement chain because people here are so smart. Might be better fit to work at a smaller company
advice-to-mgmt: Keep raising the stock, work hard and lead by example through this internet bubble 2.0. Emphasize more on the self driving car

pros: The perks are legendary here. Contrary to rumors, the food quality is still very good, some of the newer cafes on the main campus get rave reviews. Get to work with lots of very smart people, with mostly good attitudes. Very academic atmosphere where research and analysis of data is the preferred way to guide decisions.
cons: Very crowded campuses, easy to feel lost in a sea of employees. Free food, but nowhere to sit down and eat it. Not always easy to spend time on "20 percent time" projects as advertised. Lots of internal bureaucracy, surveys, and distractions of optional employee-oriented programs. Self-promotion is encouraged, so prepare to toot your own horn and compete for recognition of your project if you want to get promoted
advice-to-mgmt: Work to simplify day-to-day life, shave off unnecessary perks, split up main site to more smaller campuses to avoid the overcrowded feeling.

pros: Benefits Hourly Rate Professional Development Speaker Series Lunches with executives TGIF or TGIT Perks AMAZING CULTURE Top talent
cons: Could be more diverse but they are working hard on changing this. Their efforts are valued. It shows commitment to the cause and highlights the amazing core values of the company.
advice-to-mgmt: Keep hiring great people with varied life experiences to continue to grow and innovate.

pros: Lots of opensource , good environment
cons: food is not good. tasty is not good too.

pros: Lots of mobility, opportunities to be creative and take the lead.
cons: With the company being so large, sometimes it's difficult to get significant recognition of novel work.

pros: Lots of perks - amazing free food, micro kitchens stocked with snacks and any kind of beverage you'd want, baristas, fitness center, subsidized massages and more. They compensation is generous and most of the employees are very fun, nice and smart.
cons: -There is not a lot of opportunity in the Cambridge office to advance for non-engineering positions -It is not the easiest location to get to - lots of traffic - and the garage is undergoing major construction for the next 2 years -It has turned into a big company where decisions take forever to be made and there is a lot of red tape -They say they allow flexibility but everything is up to an individual manager's discretion so there is hardly anyone that is part time and almost every job requires travel
advice-to-mgmt: Provide more non-eng opportunity for satellite offices and more opportunity/real guidelines for flexible positions

pros: Google is a great company at the forefront of technological advancement. The pay and hours are good and the work culture is laid back.
cons: There are enough talented people that being talented won't guarantee you an inside track on good projects, because there are thousands of equally smart people ahead in the queue and equally underutilized, but there are just enough bozos that you have to prove that you're not one of them
advice-to-mgmt: Any improvement not based on a hard metric was flatly not a respected use of time. Usability? Number of bugs? Nobody cared. If you couldn't measure it, nobody was interested in it.

summary: Great place to work, some bureaucracy
pros: Great people, lots of perks, awesome benefits, global scope.
cons: Bureaucracy, challenges to promotion, competitive.

pros: Google has the clout and money necessary to provide all the resources necessary to succeed.
cons: I guess I didn't drink the Kool-Aid. Google has been a major success story in building the web into what it is today. However, most of the management and employees have fallen in love with their own intelligence. This is very bad news for the future growth of the company. Additionally, Google is very risk adverse no matter that they have a "moonshot" factory. They don't stick to their goals when there are set backs.
advice-to-mgmt: Pick employees that have relevant experience in the areas you are working on. Generalists work well in software but specialists are needed in most every other field.

pros: Tremendous opportunity to learn and develop a deep understanding of how global scale technologies and companies need to work. Huge investment in human capital
cons: Huge scale can be overwhelming As with all companies, there are office politics at least everyone is trying to be Googlely
advice-to-mgmt: Focus on what Google does best, be wary of distractions and spreading too thin

pros: Growth potential, benefits, innovation, community contribution, health care,
cons: I can not think of any

summary: Great coworkers, and oppurtunities for advancement
pros: I've gone from a new grade hire to the tech lead of a 8 person team in 2 1/2 years, and I've learned a ton along the way. Not every engineer you'll work with is amazing, some are just good, and a few are mediocre. However, so many are amazing that it's an absolute pleasure to work on the same codebase as they do.  And the top people are actually quite accessible - I've had questions I've sent to mailing lists get answered by the authors of the Java memory model, the Android framework, and BoringSSL.
cons: Mountain View-centric attitude leads to extreme commute times. This is the largest negative about working here, and I probably would have left by now if I wasn't able to work from home or the SF office most of the week. I'm sure if you live in boring suburbia it'd be fine, but I don't want to do that.

pros: good working environment, handsome salary,good growth and free lunch. you will learn lot of new things, diverse working environment.
cons: no cons as it is good company

pros: Every perk you can imagine!
cons: Company is getting too big to maintain well-known culture standards

summary: Mostly positive, although a bad internship experience can scar prospective graduates
pros: Lots of accomplished and diverse engineers around you, best practices are very refined, mentorship and sense of community between teams and buildings is very strong if you are willing to participate!
cons: so large scale (hopefully more addressable with the new restructuring) that similar projects spawn at different offices that couldve been better generalized and collaborated on if there had been a better platform for discovering ongoing or pitched projects. Had a very positive experience with my first internship, but my second felt more overbearing and too broad to be polished on delivery by the end of my internship. If you are considering interning here, make sure you discuss your project's scope and depth before you decide to take on a team - most teams do a great job of this, but mine was fairly new and grew quickly which meant I ended up doing lots of proof of concept work and design reviews for code to replace obsolete peripheral code (for more context, the project goal was Android, but I spent a bulk of my internship doing design reviews and proof of concept deployment of a whole new backend and only 4 weeks on Android development).

pros: Excellent pay and benefits (by far the best software engineering pay I've seen in the Boston area). Higher bonus and stock than anywhere else, too. Extremely competent coworkers. Some interesting projects if you look for them. Work/life balance (read as 40 hrs workweek) is doable but you may feel a bit guilty about it as many self-impose longer hours or at least check email at crazy hours.
cons: Can be hard to feel like you're making an impact or get recognition in such a large company, especially a remote office. Most of the really interesting projects are in the Mountain View office. Kendall location is convenient to the T but not so great if you're looking to settle down outside of the city.

pros: Great benefits, work life balance, growth opportunities. Promoted to lead expansion in new geos within 2 years. Fun outings and team building
cons: Bureaucracy at times like any other companies. Consensus driven culture. Senior management is sometimes managing up rather than down, which can be frustrating

pros: Great place to work and build your career.
cons: Too much Work! I had to work almost 6 days a week everyday.

pros: Great environment, lots of opportunities
cons: None that i can think of.

pros: Perks are too many to mention and with so many smart people to follow around you're going to learn a lot!
cons: For most I think the small impact you can make, because there is so much talent there and roles can be narrowly defined.

summary: Great culture, hard to navigate layers at times
pros: Great culture, it's up to you to make your impact, amazing technology, treat us like adults, food's awesome, total comp is really great (current stock price really helps!)
cons: Things change so quickly that it can be difficult to figure out the right way to get something done. Tools get deprecated so quickly that it's a constant race to make sure valuable tools continue to get updated and work. Growing fast so office space is really becoming an issue.
advice-to-mgmt: Sometimes the balance between getting products out early to test them and getting them complete errs too much on the side of getting them out early.

pros: * Friendly and smart co worker * Good management which does not micro-manage * Nice products and teams to work with.
cons: * Its a big company, a little bureaucracy is creeping in. * Lots of competition, getting promoted can be hard at times.

pros: it was awesome I really liked the culture of Google. I loved coming to work everyday.
cons: I don't really see any cons of working at google. I decided to leave because I wanted to be closer to my family
advice-to-mgmt: I don't have anything specific to say about management. They allowed you to grow and work your style

pros: Great place to work at. Literally has everything you need to work, eat, and play.
cons: There are no cons with Google. This is the best company in the world.
advice-to-mgmt: No need to double check on the progress because we got in under control.

pros: I was experiencing great fulfillment working for such great Company, using my linguistic skills and Italian culture in a multicultural environment.
cons: Salary compensation was unsatisfying and inadequate for the high quality professional performances provided.

summary: Great company. Work depends on which team you are at.
pros: Great culture. Company really puts employee first.
cons: Getting bigger with more hierarchy.

pros: flexible working hours and the work-life balance
cons: you cannot make intelligent decisions

pros: Great place to work, lots of places to eat and drink
cons: Too many people, too many visitors

pros: You'll get to work with a lot of smart folks...
cons: ...who spend a lot of time being code janitors.

pros: Great coworkers, lots of opportunities
cons: Harder to transfer between roles

summary: Currently the best large company to work for.
pros: Google has a very open culture. Granted, being a large company, its ideals aren't always met, but the the culture of the company is to constantly strive to meet them. Among all the current large companies in the world, the culture is vastly superior.  They are also one of the highest payers in the field when comparing total compensation. Of course, the facilities are pretty legendary.
cons: It spoils you. If you ever leave, it would be very hard to work somewhere else.

pros: Great people, Great culture and Wonderful opportunities.
cons: Too many great people. Too many debates on the scope of the product.
advice-to-mgmt: Continue what you are doing and please keep churning out great innovative products.

pros: Constant change Incredibly bright colleagues Collaborative environment Cutting edge projects Ruth Porat, our new CFO who is doing great things
cons: Constant change (depends on how you look at it, I see it as a positive) Becoming a "big" company

pros: great perks and great work environment.
cons: small fish in a big sea.

pros: Open culture, fast moving, dynamic, ambitious, lots of perks, strong culture
cons: getting very large and a bit bureaucratic, certain parts of the company can be political, less opportunities for people at the director level and up. Certain parts of the business - like Android and Play - have little work / life balance. Little appreciation of marketing in certain businesses that are entrenched monopolies.
advice-to-mgmt: Provide more guidance and opportunities for director level employees

pros: 1. The job is challenging and you get to learn. 2. Your teammates and colleague are generally very very smart and relatively nice.
cons: 1. Promotion is hard. It depends on not only your performance, but also how your team's status, and some relatively random decision. 2. It's a very demanding job. You have really high peer pressure if you want to stand out.
advice-to-mgmt: 1. More encouragement for creativity. 2. More support for promotion. 3. Less micro managing.

summary: Great place to start your career
pros: Smart and engaging coworkers, free food/beverages, free transportation, free parking, access to Google events, free massages
cons: Expected to work at maintain quick pace, even for sales. The pace makes it difficult to enjoy all of the pros listed above.

pros: Good perks, food, general Google lifestyle
cons: Bad middle management, political, slow moving

pros: -Amazing coworkers and teammates -Flexible work culture that's inspiring and motivating -Challenging work environment focused on personal development and growth with ability to focus on innovative projects with autonomy and support -Work life balance is truly encouraged at Google, people are hard working and smart and get their job done while balancing other prioroitis
cons: -Navigating career changes internally can be challenging. Just because you're at the company doesn't mean the process is necessarily easier for changing roles -Can feel like a competitive environment at times but this is due to the fact that it's filled with high performing, over-achievers vs. actual competition

pros: Culture of innovation, appreciation for strong performance, high value placed on quality managers.
cons: As the company grows, it takes longer to make decisions and get things done.
advice-to-mgmt: Get rid of low performers even more quickly.

summary: The benefits are not worth the scarifies
pros: Good food. Good co-workers, Opportunities to leave the comapny
cons: Work and life balance, no time off, the future of the company is all based on moonshots. The core products are doing well, but could have the stool pulled from under them at any moment.

pros: Free food, nice environment, decent salary, good company reputation, and a lot more great things.
cons: Overall great experience, haven't found any.

summary: After 2 years, can't think of a reason to leave
pros: (1) Countless perks that probably adds 20% to your base salary (including free food, transportation, gym, dance/sports classes, etc)  (2) Working with smart/Googley people (you can easily schedule one-to-one meetings with Googlers that are willing to teach a certain topic)  (3) Working for a company that cares about its employees
cons: (1) Too many smart people, too much conflict. There is saying in Google, "Welcome to Google, where impossible stuff is easy, and easy stuff is impossible"  (2) The company is now huge so we are seeing less and less collaboration between products.
advice-to-mgmt: Make sure your employees think about Google as a whole. You can see cases where each product is only optimizing for their own team without thinking about the impact on different areas of the business.

pros: Great work Envirnoment and friendly staff.
cons: No cons that I can think of

pros: Google offers real challenge to employees that want to work hard
cons: Working hard can include long hours, weekends, accommodating global timezones and other difficulties. This is not a 9-5 company. Moving up can be incredibly slow.

pros: Free meals, Easy going, laid back work environment.
cons: Internal politics sometimes prevents you from growth

pros: Google is a good place to work with free food and great perks. the 20% time to work on own projects is a bit blown though
cons: This company is going the big wigs way. The 20% time to work on own projects is over blown and you really dont get this much time.
advice-to-mgmt: do not be reactive to technology but proactive. google android though has good market penetration just mimics what apple does.

pros: Opportunity to grow, training and integrity, people will feel good about themselg
cons: Diversity of employee not close to home or lack of individual recognition.
advice-to-mgmt: By providing job security, and excellent health benefits people will be satisfied to work in your company.

summary: Being a Student Ambassador is pretty cool!
pros: They fly you out to Mountain View HQ over summer to get trained for a few days. You learn about the Google culture, explore their offices, and have fun with the other Ambassadors. All the Ambassadors stay in a hotel. During the daytime, you have a bunch of workshops at the offices and free food. At night you go back to the hotels and PARTY! Jk, well you can. Oh and everything is ALL EXPENSE PAID!
cons: They dont really give you that much spending money during the school year for your marketing events. Communication is very poor during the school year as well.

summary: Not as great as it used to be.
pros: Salaries are competitive. Perks and benefits are great. The culture of "do no evil." is still alive.
cons: It's be come too big and too bureaucratic. Too many rules and red tape to go through to get anything done, even when trying to change roles or projects. HR is too diplomatic, not really interested in helping employees, they're more concern about preventing Google from being sued. Google's annual survey is there, but haven't seen anything come of it. Work life balance isn't balanced anymore. It's more work, less of a life, if you want to keep getting good performance reviews. Tough to draw the line when your colleagues and boss are sending emails at 11 o'clock at night.
advice-to-mgmt: Lighten up! Stop pushing employees to think bigger and bigger and bigger.... how much more can we do and still breathe? Haven't you noticed how many incredibly talented employees you're losing? If I'm gonna work 60+ hours a week, why not go to a start-up?

pros: Nice environment, good food, many fun
cons: The funs are distracting a little bit.

job-title: Former Employee - Marketing and Field Sales Representative
summary: Great company, but you're still a contract worker
pros: -Food -Great co-workers -Fun culture -Good name brand
cons: -Contract workers do not get PTO, sick leave, or any trips/perks as Google employees -Your "boss" isn't really your boss, you report to your contract company...makes it really confusing -Zero to no growth potential
advice-to-mgmt: Hire Fiber employees, quit contracting them out

pros: The best part of the job is when you just talk with your mates and have fun because thats what it is all about.
cons: Some of the people are rude and don't listen to you so just make sure to select the right teammates in your groups.

summary: This is an exciting, interesting and satisfying place to work.
pros: The work is interesting, and not tedious or boring. The expectations are not unreasonable. There is room to grow, ands expand ones skill set using the 20% time. Coworkers are amazing and one learns a lot. Perks are pretty awesome
cons: It is hard to get noticed. The imposter syndrome is strong. Promotions require extraordinary work. It really pastas to be self motivating, and self promoting. You need to get decent per reviews from your co workers

pros: Great Company. The food is amazing. The people are brilliant, and the passion is palpable!
cons: There is a lot of flux at the company (re-orgs on a regular basis), which makes it hard to keep your feet under you. Working at Google and excelling means either being really flexible and quick, or being inflexible and driving forward with your projects no matter the environment.

pros: Great benefits and friendly people. Never had a terrible day here.
cons: Expensive area to live in

pros: Lots of potential for learning on exciting projects
cons: Company has grown to be large

pros: Relaxed atmosphere means you aren't having your back watched. Folks can inflate their performance if they want and don't have to work too hard. Probably put in realistically about 30 hours per week of real work. Great benefits including free meals, free barista, free juice bar, free on-site gym with trainers, lots of events including on-site presenters. Local and Global perks including discounts on EVERYTHING much like AAA does for their customers. You get 20% off Sonos, Nest and just about any brand out there.
cons: Some real politics are going on these days. You will find the global business organization (their sales division) is more risk averse and people can be back-stabbing in your own team to get political gain. The performance review process is very flawed. They don't tell you what goes into it and therefore you may or may not get promoted and don't know why. Play the politics game and that will help you win. Make up inflated things around thought-leadership even if there is no sales component tied to it and you'll see you may get promoted.
advice-to-mgmt: Get your performance review process under control. Stop rewarding the internal folks who posture and create a false sense of high contribution. Create more sprint teams who x-functionally collaborate to get cool stuff done. Break the barriers and silos that have shown up the last few years.

pros: Great benefits, opportunity to work with smart individuals. NYC building is gorgeous.
cons: Incredibly competitive environment translates into always having to 'watch your back.' Based on my experience, I would say the Engineer culture is very different from the Sales/Business culture. The Sales/Business culture can be stodgy, dry, and incredibly 'corporate.' Training can be very difficult to find at times, which ultimately slows down ramp-up time.
advice-to-mgmt: Joining Google, from an outsiders perspective, can be overwhelming. Learning the culture alone can take several months (if not longer), and finding the right training tools can be difficult. Arguably, this falls on the hiring manager to point Nooglers in the right direction, but some managers at Google aren't built to onboard Nooglers (nor have the patience). I've seen "bad" managers do better with Googlers who transferred departments internally.  Separately, based on my experience, many employees are complacent. Getting into Google is admittedly difficult, and quite the accomplishment. Due to this, I feel that some employees no longer have the passion nor drive to excel in their careers. They "fall in line" , enjoy the benefits, and wait for their turn to get promoted. It can be a (very) frustrating environment for some.

pros: I am a people person, that I love to meet different people that makes your work environment goes really smooth.
cons: Some of the challenges of working here are making sure that all the residents are taken care of and care for like they're supposed to be

summary: Wonderful place to work and develop a breadth of skills
pros: Strong culture, lots of really smart people from whom you can learn a lot. Great resources, every aspect of company is innovative and doesn't settle for OK. Fun environment.
cons: Big company, outside of your immediate team/department there isn't a strong sense of local community. It's hard to see impact importance of your work if you're in a large organization.  Managers can be hit or miss. Decision-making / getting things done can be difficult in a large organization (bureaucracy or "too many cooks in the kitchen").
advice-to-mgmt: Don't get stuck in the details and forget to see the forest from the trees. Try to fight the culture of entitlement and encourage more expressions of mutual gratitude amongst employees.

pros: 1. Good procedure 2. Everyone is nice 3. The interviewers are really friendly 4. Flight is very flexible
cons: 1. Not too high salary 2. Technical interview is very difficult 3. No leetcode problems 4. New problems never saw before
advice-to-mgmt: The company is too big. It is really difficult to get promoted. So you might work very hard, or you do not work at all.

pros: free snacks Things to do interesting projects would work there again for sure
cons: Long hours not so much fun projects occasionally disorganized structure at times long interview process
advice-to-mgmt: work more to ensure reasonable work life balance accommodate working families and those with outside of work commitments continue giving employees free time!

pros: Good money, good people, good food. Everyone I've worked with at Google has been a pleasure to work with.
cons: Working for such a large company means it takes longer to get anything done. As an iOS developer, Google does iOS development very differently from other companies. Traffic is a pain getting in and out of campus.

pros: You can take it easy.
cons: Job can be repetitive and boring. Nothing new to learn.

pros: good food and coffee free
cons: annoying people hipsterish always wants to talk

pros: very fun place to work, lots of smart people
cons: it was a lot of hard work, but thats expected

pros: it's generous to engineers, and more
cons: much brain wash, and more

summary: Great company, but gone a bit corporate
pros: It's Google. You work with smart people, work on interesting projects, and have fantastic perks. Work life balance was surprisingly good.
cons: Hiring can be a mess and take forever. There's a lot of either deprecated technology in the stack or tech that is not ready to use.

pros: Imagine a place that you are working with the 20% people all the time, this is how it is working in Google. You can trust your co-working to get their part done almost 90+% of the time without nagging them.
cons: Still have politics. The company is large, so some things don't get done as quickly. Some overachievers are trying very hard to shine. If you are aggressive and try to climb the corporate ladder than the competition can be tough.
advice-to-mgmt: Please don't change the Google culture.

pros: Great benefits and work-life balance, smart people and interesting products
cons: Limited career opportunities given size of company.

job-title: Former Employee - Manager, Global Communications &amp, Public Affairs
pros: Google provides an opportunity to work with super smart, engaged people on exciting, fast-moving projects that have a huge impact. The wonderful benefits don't hurt, either.
cons: All the frustrations of working in a large, flat organization: especially if you're trying to get anything done cross-functionally, takes awhile to figure out how "the world works" and deal with navigating the organizational structure. Where I was in the organization, pace and rapid change of projects could be challenging at times.
advice-to-mgmt: More emphasis on developing and valuing people managers. Continue work on crowd-sourcing bureaucracy-busting ideas and continue dedication to transparency.

pros: work with smart people laid back environment learned a lot.
cons: last minute unplanned meetings can be a bit frustrating.

summary: Still a great place to work but slowly maturing
pros: Culture, People, Experience, Mobility, Pace
cons: Becoming a large corporation with the usual challenges

pros: loved everything about it. was a fun place to work
cons: none everything was exeptional i had a great time

pros: Lots of perks: free food, free gym, on site massages, great opportunities to learn about different areas of the business, excellent coworkers-a pleasure to work with most people at Google.
cons: Work-life balance could be better. Certain projects seem understaffed. Lots of bureaucracy, which can be frustrating to some people. Not too many cons overall
advice-to-mgmt: None, a great place to work

pros: Smart people Tons of interesting projects Lots of new cool things to learn and contribute Other perks such as free food, massages etc
cons: Company is becoming bigger so there is lot of competition for projects and promotions. Apart from that there is nothing else I can think of.

pros: Great campus and intern culture
cons: The shuttle schedules were sometimes hard to work around

summary: Excellent first company to join after college. Best launchpad for career.
pros: Excellent first company to join after college. Best launchpad for career.
cons: Promotions are based on politics. For management & HR: Many TLMs pick favorites and reduce opportunities for others by restricting project allocations. Encourage 6-month transfers to help employees find better and cohesive teams where they will happily remain and let others move. It'll also let bad teams / TLs get smaller and atrophy which is good for Google overall.
advice-to-mgmt: Many TLMs pick favorites and reduce opportunities for others by restricting project allocations. Encourage 6-month transfers to help employees find better and cohesive teams where they will happily remain and let others move. It'll also let bad teams / TLs get smaller and atrophy which is good for Google overall.

pros: good easy, fun, good management, smart
cons: not enough work, not worth it

pros: free food, massages, co workers and environment
cons: nothing really except you don't get to choose which state you'd like to be placed in when you're entry level but a great company either way

pros: Free stuff is pretty awesome
cons: Hard to go up as a contractor
advice-to-mgmt: Chill out for second and stop the INTENSE bureaucracy

pros: Tales of terrible work-life balance are exaggerated, tales of lavish benefits are not. 9-5 or 10-6 are pretty standard working hours, although some choose to work longer.  Managers are explicitly there to help you get ahead in your career - most take that to heart and act accordingly.  Strong culture of engineering well, rather than fast. Unit testing, code coverage, automated sanity checks, peer reviews, etc are the norm.  VERY socially responsible company, even more than they like to advertise. It's easy to feel proud to work for a company acting very intentionally to do great things for the world.
cons: The open office layout is noisy and distracting - it's possible to cope, but I really wish we had separate cubes or offices.  Being social is required to get ahead. Everyone has a high level of competence coming in, so you get ahead through collaboration, leadership, impact, and other things that are difficult to do if you're not a social person.

pros: Great company, lots of interesting work, great coworkers, upward mobility.
cons: Frustrating management at times, hard to feel meanginful with so many people, tiring work sometimes.
advice-to-mgmt: Invest more in training, work on building connections with employers, be more relatable. Be realistic.

pros: Bright and engaging people, amazing financial and non-financial benefits, healthy work life balance. Easily the biggest advantage of working at Google is the people, extremely intelligent, team oriented, and genuine.
cons: Occasional long hours, high achieving culture with fast operations. On the sales/marketing side of the house, it's expected to be constantly connected to, and to have very fast TATs for asks, both client and internal.
advice-to-mgmt: Continue to focus on fostering a culture of openness, feedback, inclusion, and high expectation. The annual employee survey is a critical tool in gauging organizational health, so continue to evaluate this critically and address opportunities in an open forum.

pros: Flex time and once you leave work your day is done.
cons: No room to become full time none contract.. Pay is on the low end.

pros: awesome people, great perks, best place to launch a career.
cons: big company, need to learn skills to deal with it.

pros: very engaging and creative work
cons: very competitive and high stress

summary: Few better companies int he world
pros: Visionary leadership, interesting products, great brand, great perks, very focused on employee development/growth
cons: As it gets larger, it gets slower, more dysfunctional, less efficient.
advice-to-mgmt: Empower product leaders to make decisions, demand fast action. Be okay with failing and moving on.

pros: really great opportunity to network and meet new people.
cons: Long hours (55+) as an unpaid intern.
advice-to-mgmt: Have fewer "mandatory fun" events after close of business, and let your unpaid interns go home

pros: Its a great environment and i love it
cons: great workers and great food

summary: Great place, high learning curve but a lot of fun
pros: Passionate people Great benefits Really good work life balance Management is strong here, haven't met many of the annoying PMs that don't understand engineering.
cons: It can be daunting to start since you have to get used to all the tools (there are a lot of tools, especially Google specific tools).
advice-to-mgmt: Diversify products but don't forget about focusing on building features in products that draw in the most users

pros: Amazing food, perks, people, etc
cons: I can not think of anything

summary: Great company, not great middle management

summary: Excellent culture and mission, but some orgs are bureaucratic
pros: Wonderful mission from the founders and leaders, which truly trickle down to every aspect of the company. Employees feel connected and included in the amazing contributions made from the entire Google workforce. You can tell that the founders truly do have idealistic notions that permeate the culture and create an atmosphere that is difficult to find and authentically recreate.
cons: Depending on the department, bureaucracy can quite a problem. There were obvious ways to make things better, but the top leaders were either uninvolved and focused on other 'sexier' projects, or were never given the honest/critical information. Inefficiencies weren't fixed because teams and departments were built around how things worked (not optimally). This led to management pushing and trying to exceed targets in a non-optimal system, rather than trying to fix the system itself. Some employees were incentivized to get promotions by garnering attention, rather than improving and fixing real problems to improve the product and user's experience.
advice-to-mgmt: AdWords is your bread and butter, so it is worth your attention because it fuels all the innovative projects Google undertakes. Look at the satisfaction of customers, how often they leave the platform, and finally, how the sales people, the ones who actually interact with customers, are measured in terms of performance. Basically, they're incentivized to get customers to do as many actions as possible - whether or not those actions are actually good for the customer. It's a simple platform, and employees are smart people. There is no need for an overly complex points system when you can have metrics that get to the heart of the question, like: is this sales person offering helpful, meaningful, technically sound yet easy to understand advice? (Customer survey) Is this sales person improving the advertising success of the customer? (AdWords metrics which are easily accessible) Please improve the incentives model. I want to see Google do well and it is hard to see employees doing what is only right for them and not the user. The system needs to be fixed.

summary: Great Place for MBAs...If you can hold out on a hiring decision

cons: Long time for a hiring decision for MBA full-time and intern roles.

pros: Great to stay in google with open atmosphere

pros: Great benefits and international career opps. Great infraestructure and facilities. Great work and life balance. Very smart people at several positions.
cons: Middle managment at sales psitions tends to be mediocre. No attrition mechanisms. The company is willing to loose top performers instead of trying to keep them at Google.
advice-to-mgmt: Top maangement does an extraordinary job. The same cannotnbe said about several departments, such as HR. Hiring the best and brightest has stopped being a moto of the company.

summary: Wouldn't call it the best place to work...
pros: The basics, free food, good benefits (but now most tech companies have the same benefits), a lot of good people.
cons: No direction, guidance or training. It was literally sink or swim. The content of what we were working on was not interesting or challenging and when tried to shift to other projects, we were told that we could only do this one thing. Usually a good manager will help their employees find a project where they can build their strengths. I think they didn't really care if we left, but thought, "hey we can always hire more, we are Google" - they treated employees as disposable. There was no flexibility for the team we were on, we were micromanaged and they didn't treat us like adults. Our manager was not interested in building our individual careers or supporting us, but just running the business at a strategic level and would constantly cancel meetings for personal reasons.  Some people were obsessed about working at Google, almost like it was a sorority or fraternity and it was a little cultish. Even one of my friends said when I worked there, all I did was talk about working there.
advice-to-mgmt: Actually try to promote and develop those who are good managers and encourage them to develop their employees. Treat people like adults and give them a bit more flexibility to get the job done.

cons: Bad career path. Most people stop at T5. To reach T6, you have to fight for leadership and ownership. Communication overhead due to the sheer size of the company. Personal growth. While you are exposed to interesting and technical deep projects, you are likely to get lost on how the entire infrastructure works. Bad if you want to build skills for running or joining startups.

summary: Great company, but your mileage WILL vary.
pros: * Google has, bar none, some of the best office schemes I've ever seen. Their conference room layouts make a lot of sense, and the designs and liveliness pouring through those walls were on another level.  * There are tons and tons AND TONS of teams at Google working on close to anything that you can think of, technical or not, and transferring between them is actually encouraged as long as you're on good standing performance-wise.  * Feedback is taken very seriously at Google. It's paramount to their culture and it shows: the Food department cares a lot about turning out high-quality food, People Ops does everything they can to make the employee experience a happy one, etc. Even though it's kind-of a talking piece now, the TGIF sessions with Larry, Sergey and top management are unprecedented.  * The food is quite good most of the time. Some of it's restaurant-quality, even. (It highly depends on the cafe you go to and the food you typically eat.)  * Aside from a tech startup, I can't think of any other place that's on the bleeding edge of technology at this scale. Google is highly, highly experimental, almost to a fault. (More on that in the "Cons.")  * Their benefits are really generous for a large org. They're not insanely so compared to others like them, but all of the basics (and then some!) are covered.  * If you like free stuff, Google will bury you with it over time. I didn't work there very long but somehow got two backpacks, a few shirts and a hoodie. Interns get way more stuff, though.
cons: A lot of the cons below are projections of my experience at Google. Do a TON of research on the role you'll be applying for. Find people on LinkedIn. Scour reddit. Learn as much as you possibly can about what you'll be doing to try and prepare for what's to come.  * Your experience at Google will largely depend on your team and/or manager. If you join a bad team and/or a bad manager, you'll be in for a rough 12 months (the minimum amount of time that's usually required to transfer out.)  * ANYTHING you do or create outside of work is owned by Google, regardless of whether you used their resources or not to do it. This could be a HUGE issue for you if you contribute heavily to open-source and/or like to build side projects. Google's People Ops **do** look out for people doing this too.  * The compensation is okay depending on where you're coming from, but salary is practically non-negotiable (stock units are more flexible, though) and might not even be competitive depending on your area. Lots of funded startups and finance shops pay significantly better for the same level of experience. Additionally, compensation doesn't scale relative to growth. One could double their salary or more within the same amount of time it takes to get from mid-range to senior at Google.  * Almost everything that an engineer at Google uses on a daily basis is home-grown and maintained by other Googlers. Much of this tooling is incredibly complicated and takes months to warm up to. This could be a MAJOR brain drain to consider depending on your career path and/or whether you're thinking of staying at Google long-term. (That said, some of the tools were pretty good, though I usually preferred third-party alternatives for many of the others I worked with.)  * Most of the sexy projects that makes Google Google are in Mountain View, and if you really want to take your career at Google seriously, you'll eventually have to move out there. Living costs in the Bay are insane and show no signs of restoring sanity any time soon.  * Despite having all of the infrastructure to support it, remotely working is generally discouraged by most teams. That said, many, MANY meetings are done completely or partially with Hangouts and Google's solution for accessing internal resources from public endpoints is probably the best there is.  * Their interview process is generally terrible. Engineers at Google generally don't like to interview and/or provide feedback, so the interview experience for potential candidates varies wildly across the board. The process also takes a really long time. It took me about four months to get to the offer stage, apparently, that's normal there. (To put this into perspective, I've worked at places that took a week from cold start to signed offer, they can't possibly not be losing talent from these insane delays.)  * I don't remember seeing more people glued to their phone or laptop in a single workplace before coming here. It seems like almost everyone travels while glued to their phone here. It's maddening.  * Most interviews are focused almost entirely on technical merit. This makes it (much) more likely for engineers with strong technical skills but (very) weak social skills to make it through the cracks. If you're more outgoing and "extroverted," this might bother you. (It bothered me to no end.)  * There's lots of exciting work being done at Google, but more exciting work usually means even more operational work. A lot of extremely capable people get slotted into doing that sort of work. Do as much research as you can on your role to give you an idea of what you're getting into.  * Technical merit is placed above all else as an engineer. Because this is a significant determinant in promotion decisions, a lot of people spend a lot of time doing "complex and impactful" work at the expense of things like documentation or maintainability. As you might imagine, this leads to a lot of reinvented wheels and deprecation. (It doesn't help that every project seemingly *has* to have a name to it that might or might not have anything to do with the project that describes it.)  * Work-life balance HIGHLY depends on your team. In my experience, people at Google that spent a lot of time working after-hours did so on their own volition (for better or worse). Management never pressured me to work more than I wanted to, in fact, they've had to tell people to ease up!
advice-to-mgmt: You really need to pay your people better. The market's catching up to you. Discouraging remote workers made more sense in 2003 than it does now. Aside from that, a lot of Googlers seem to be happy and proud of being Googlers and I can't blame them. Building a 50,000+ person company that isn't a behemoth of drones is pretty hard to pull off!

summary: A great big company to work for, but it's still big
pros: Huge infrastructure for employee benefits. Low risk. Work with smart people. Free food is convenient and healthy. Buses make the commute more tolerable. People usually given a high degree of independence and trust.
cons: Senior leadership basically full with old timers. One-size fits all process and lack of transparency for benefits, promotions, and salary can be frustrating. Cultures vary widely from team to team in terms of diversity/bias, expected work hours, or positive energy.
advice-to-mgmt: Expand non-MTV offices to mitigate problems with commuting. Fix HR so it's not a black hole for complaints where nothing gets addressed. Empower more team members to address issues with under performers, especially those who just disappear for months at a time.

summary: One of the best companies for software engineers ever
pros: - high impact projects/teams - smart people - lots of projects and mobility between them - perks/benefits are amazing (12 weeks Paterntity leave?!?!) - don't be evil is still very real (at least better than many big companies this size), though there are obviously varying opinions in 100k employees
cons: - everyone is so smart, it's hard to stand out - expect high-level of efficiency/productivity - harder for low-level engineers to have high individual impact (you get impact by working on projects that have LOTS of users)
advice-to-mgmt: Open up a ycombinator equivalent for your engineers to go away for 12 weeks and try to start a company. Take 5-7% in the company and provide them the same perks/benefits that yc has

pros: Great benefits, and get to work with some brilliant folk.
cons: After recent restructuring it will be difficult for people in the Alphabet companies to move about between projects, which will limit future opportunities. The interview process makes it difficult for good people to come in, outside of being acquired.
advice-to-mgmt: Actively manage under performers into projects that will help them be successful and move on.

pros: Free food free naps free massages cool and brilliant coworkers. Cool projects. Amazing campus. Shuttle buses. Interesting opportunities for career advancement
cons: upper management doesn't take middle management seriously.
advice-to-mgmt: Please listen to your employees and contractors. Let them be the voice of expertise in their field. That's why they're there.

pros: Excellent food and the location is good for many activities.
cons: Public transportation is not very convenient

pros: Everything is great to work for google.
cons: Pay sucks and management is not very good with people.

summary: Managed personnel within google's call center
pros: Good communication in management Innovative working environment More vacation time Employee collaboration and engaging work groups
cons: Extensive hiring process and long hours of work
advice-to-mgmt: allow more employee creativity within the work environment.

pros: They have a great starting salary if you go to a top teir college and the people are so wonderful
cons: It's far from where I live and the business is Huge so you cant get to meet everyone
advice-to-mgmt: They should hire more mbas from top teir svhools like ucla or berkeley or harvard or columbia or princeton

pros: Huge level of responsibility and interesting work
cons: Commuting to Mt View on the bus

pros: Lots of smart people, challenging work, and flexibility to move around to different teams.
cons: Can be very stressful at first and work/life balance can be difficult (depending on the team).

pros: Good compensation and benefits. Depending on the team, work can be interesting. Usually everybody on the team is smart.
cons: Stress of the job can be high, especially if there is management turnover and frequent changes in priorities. Feeling like I have to compete with team mates.

pros: Good pay Lots of responsibility High exposure
cons: Horrible systems Long work hours Demanding culture

pros: Food is very very good
cons: Busy busy busy very busy

pros: Amazing management, perks, food, fun, coworkers, atmosphere, it was just a wonderful place to work.
cons: potential long hours depending on your time management, also requires lots of friendliness and networking which is great unless you're an introvert

pros: Awesome place to work at. The perks are the best in the industry. Great Place to be.
cons: No Opportunity to grow. Very data centric. Collaboration needs to be focused on.

pros: Great People. Great Culture. Great Benefits.
cons: Limited upward mobility in remote offices.

pros: Great benefits and company culture.
cons: Lots of competition for positions and slow up-ward mobility

pros: Relaxing work environment. Free food. Good benefits like 401k.
cons: Many teams with uninteresting projects. Impact is limited.

pros: Entrepreneurial culture, very dynamic projects. The teams are made up of some of people with some of the most diverse backgrounds I have ever seen.
cons: Google is obviously a large company so sometimes it's difficult to feel your individual work is making a difference in the larger scope.
advice-to-mgmt: I would suggest continually focusing on the professional development of the employees, particularly the younger ones. Competing companies are definitely following suit in the Google perks, the company should differentiate itself in exit opps, post-Google.

pros: Treat employees really well Very nice culture Campus is like a University Google is changing the world!!
cons: Nothing Not sure what else I can say To really express the fact that there are no Cons in working at Google
advice-to-mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing 😀

pros: Great opportunity for growth. Smart people Lots of food! A huge opportunity to learn, a great place to start. Good management
cons: Felt I was always competing. More of a corporate atmosphere than I expected Always passing on work to higher ups, never really get to see the big picture.
advice-to-mgmt: Don't forget where you came from, try and talk to lower level employees more often.

pros: Work/life balance. Feel like you are part of the company. Hard to be affected by cliques. Good abstraction of promo process. Rewarded for good work.
cons: Gained 20lbs. Everyone is smart so not so easy to stand out. Headcount has not slowed for 5 years. Over crowded.

pros: The salary is high, I couldn't make this much anywhere else. The health benefits and other perks don't get any better than this.
cons: The company would like you to drink the Kool-Aid. I did in the beginning, and became disappointed by a lot of things. Now I look at Google as a big company that is doing it's best, and I do my best. I'm much happier now.
advice-to-mgmt: I would like to see more remote workers. It's cheaper to fly someone to Mountain View once per month than to provide them with three meals, a desk, a gym, a bus, a micro-kitchen, and enough money to rent an apartment in SF.

pros: - nobody tells you what to do, you find your own problems and solve them - lots of trust placed in you
cons: - poor middle management in sales - people are doing things for the sake of doing something that sets them apart from others

pros: Good Benefit, promising projects, nice teams
cons: Long learning progress of infrastructure

pros: Fun great excellent amazing outstan
cons: Nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing

pros: good atmosphere, team environment, hard work
cons: there were no cons ! great job!

pros: Overall Google is a great company with lots of benefits such as free food, gym, paid internet, cell phone, lots of vacation and free transportation.
cons: The organization is very flat with lots of Type A personalities meaning that its pretty cut throat to move up.

pros: Best density of talent at any large company, their office productivity suite (e.g. gmail) is definitely the best, food is quite good, especially the coffee barista
cons: Google is now a bloated, political organization. Unless you are a software engineer you will learn more elsewhere, and have greater upside at a Facebook or a start-up. HQs are in MTV, outside of there your career stagnates.
advice-to-mgmt: I worked at gTech for a portion of my time at Google - that organization is a cesspool, full of Machiavellian leaders. Split that department up so the services teams are actually aligned with product and sales.

pros: Great perks, smart people, good pay
cons: So many politics, promotions based on popularity not aptitude.
advice-to-mgmt: Promote the right people, value high performers who don't always need the spotlight and value your employees.

summary: Amazing Company - But getting too big
pros: Google set the bar for what all companies should strive for regarding culture and benefits. But the true secret to Google's success is a management philosophy of hiring the best people and trusting them to do their own work without top down hierarchical direction.
cons: Google is very, very big. Because the size of the company is so vast it can sometimes be very difficult to get things done.
advice-to-mgmt: Hire great people and guide them to do their best work.

pros: Very smart people and flexibility to choose your projects, to choose your research areas. Overall I think my coworkers are extremely well qualified for their job.
cons: Internal code base is huge, it takes long time to get familiar with it. Promotion system is a bit flaky and is not refocused on impact rather than quality

pros: Google has amazing people working there, and they are eager to help you learn as much as possible. The other benefits are just icing on the cake.
cons: There are not that many women working at Google or in leadership positions there. This negatively affects the team dynamics, for both men and women. Women reading this - apply! Aim high! You can do it!
advice-to-mgmt: Hire more women, and you will find that team productivity will drastically increase. You also will probably find that the more women you hire, the more women will stay. This will be a positive cycle (although the opposite is also true).

summary: Nothing you didn't already know about Google.
pros: Great perks, talented employees. Flexible hours, interesting projects - easy to move from team to team. Physical health prioritized with facilities on campus.
cons: Takes a while to get things done because of the size of the company you need to make sure noone else is working on what you're working on, and even if they are you can still do it anyway if you think you're better at politics.

pros: Healthcare plan Benefits and perks (when you get a chance to use it) Cool products
cons: Lack of people development Short term focus (OKRs) Questionable leadership
advice-to-mgmt: Google is a decent place to work but not as great as their image would have you believe. They don't take the time to provide constructive feedback and decision making process is lacking. If you join Google avoid Consumer Operations or gCon. I have moved from there because there was not vision, a lot of backstabbing and fingerpointing. Leadership is severely lacking which is why the attrition rate is over 35%. Other areas of Google are much more collegial in their operations

pros: Awesome culture and co-workers. Really great work life balance.
cons: None. Google was an amazing place to work!

summary: A generally excellent place to work
pros: - The people you work with! No matter what team you work on, you're going to work with lovely, interesting, and overall brilliant colleagues. The work itself and your clients are interesting and constantly changing. There is also the added benefit of plenty of opportunities for role changes and location changes all around the world
cons: - Work-life balance can vary significantly depending on what team you work on. Processes can be overly bureaucratic at times. The promotions process can be pretty opaque.
advice-to-mgmt: Keep investing in your employees and their happiness. While shareholders are important, the company doesn't run if the people who work there aren't willing to go above and beyond.

summary: Google is Great, but Becoming More Corporate
pros: They do so much for the world. Amazing projects and initiatives taking place at the company.
cons: You are not always part of those projects and initiatives. Becoming more corporate: less about what you can actually do and skills and more about politics and who you know.

pros: It is great to work with smart coworkers. It saves a lot of time in making things clear. Most of the time communication is efficient, expect when there is conflicts among senior leaders.
cons: It is become bigger and layered. Most of the time you don't know which part you are working on within the huge system.

pros: great perks, great place to be
cons: politics, process now means that the company moves more slowly that before
advice-to-mgmt: get rid of bad managers. pay attention to the perf reviews

summary: short and sweet after company was acquired
pros: benefits (plus four more words)
cons: no option to work from remote office

pros: - Talented Colleagues - Challenging problems in computing and great resources to solve them with - Great perks and benefits
cons: - Getting big - Competitors might be nimbler. - Talented colleagues also make it harder to get promoted
advice-to-mgmt: Please try to scale the organization better.

pros: Justification to purchase tools for the work is quick and easy
cons: Not many experienced hardware engineers from the industry

pros: Challenging status quo and building software for a better tomorrow.
cons: No need to change a thing, and stay the same.

pros: Smart engineers and brilliant computer science. Great facility. A rich assortment of on-campus perks. The meals. The visiting speakers. And the daily bus service helps tremendously.
cons: 1) Inexperienced and bloated middle management. 2) The white badge vs red badge situation creates conflict within departments. In this employment model, an employee sits next to a contractor, both do the exact same work but the employee gets paid 2x as much and has a full benefits packages.
advice-to-mgmt: Look to fill middle management roles with experienced people. Recruit and hire people with people and management skills, not just young smart computer folks who "need" to be promoted.

pros: Good technology, great people and huge profit from ads
cons: Some internal group (eg. corp-eng) has management that's not on par with the rest of the company.

pros: It's fun you can do whatever you want. I work on !y own schedule so I have a lot of free time
cons: I think there are no cons here, unless I lied. And I don't wanna do that

pros: Coding workflow and tools are streamlined and integrated, allowing you to focus on codin, solving problems, and working with team members.
cons: You usually work on technically fairly small things because it's a giant company with a lot of resources.

pros: They really care about your personal career path as well as your quality of life, so I got a really kind impression while I was an intern there. I also loved playing volleyball, and the Mountain View campus had great access to sand volleyball courts!
cons: I don't really have any cons! Maybe the only con was that the food is too good and too plentiful so I gained about 7 lbs during my internship :(
advice-to-mgmt: I like the way Google manages its employees, and I hope they will continue to value an employee's personal career path and support them as they transition to different teams.

pros: co-operation, High salary, new technologies ... etc
cons: very exhausted, less benefits ... etc
advice-to-mgmt: take it easy and don't race at interviews .. it's complicated

pros: money, money, money, money, money. and the free food. free trainings. money. I would have quit a long time ago were it not for the money.
cons: the politics, the pressure, the stress, the backstabbing, cutthroat colleagues, the lack of transparency, constant reorgs, lack of job security, the disposability of employees, lies from management. Human Resources team is a ship of fools.
advice-to-mgmt: Don't be evil. Don't lie about reorgs just to get rid of people you want to dispose of but can't find a legit reason to. Don't change the rules and hold employees accountable to the new rules retroactively--literally the worst thing ever, totally un-business-like.

pros: - Free Food! - Peers are helpful, intelligent, creative, and get along with pretty well. - Demos of projects makes team excited and hopeful.
cons: - Commute: 1.5 hours is alleviated by riding on the shuttle, but it is still 1.5 hrs. - Overcrowding: Open-office is somewhat distracting

pros: Mentorship is baked into the internship program. My host was great, and we had weekly meetings to review feedback for each other.
cons: I enjoyed my work but didn't feel like what I was doing was terribly important. I was also working on one of Google's smaller campuses, and there was no intern community there.

pros: Its a good job with good school medical and dental benefits
cons: A lot of tedious work and some off the people are not so great

pros: I felt like the company was truly invested in me (and my professional development) and that the people around me genuinely appreciated my contributions.
cons: I struggled with finding ways to progress my career and change verticals.

pros: Cares about employees, self-starter culture
cons: Sometimes too big and complicated to navigate, very inwardly focused

job-title: Current Employee - Associate Product Marketing Manager
summary: Great organization, but has it's internal politics
pros: The products are world-class, the company culture is amazing, and the people are some of the smartest people you'll know.  Compensation is very competitive and there's a lot of perks to keep everybody happy.
cons: Like any organization, there are internal politics that need to be navigated. Some play this well, some don't. Making sure you align yourself on the right person's good side can be tricky.

pros: Security. Google is a safe bet. Innovation is paced though, as with any developed company. All my time was spent in Google for Work org, which was very different from greater Google and had poor leadership. Was inconsequential enough that greater Google hadn't yet taken notice, but I predict a big shake up soon.
cons: Opportunity for vertical movement is scarce. Hiring practices have led to hiring candidates based on who has the best resume, rather than who is the best person for the job. Culture of ladder climbing slows down productivity and leads to a lot of people being stepped on.
advice-to-mgmt: Get back to Google. Google has grown and is still growing but this doesn't need to change the core values. Make sure that middle management is in tune with upper managements philosophies.

pros: Amazing benefits Mountain View headquarters have everything you could ever want in an office Lots of incredibly smart coworkers
cons: Terrible place to commute to if you want to live in San Francisco Easy to feel like a small cog in a big machine Limited upward mobility at this point
advice-to-mgmt: Make sure you help people grow and feel like they're making a difference. Google is such a big place that it's not very entrepreneurial anymore except for small pockets.

pros: So much fun. Great people
cons: Nothing was really wrong. It was great.

summary: Truly one of the best companies to work for
pros: The perks are awesome, specifically the gourmet food served for breakfast/lunch/dinner 5 days a week. The luxury shuttles are the most comfortable way to make the commute from SF and the 401K/health/dental plans are top notch. Super smart people and lots of projects going on that are changing the world.
cons: Google is now a large company so there's a fair amount of bureaucracy and processes in place which can slow things down. Promotions are harder to come by but this is natural for any company of this size. Google is heavily email-centric and so you better be ready for 200+ emails a day and sometimes an implicit expectation to be on email during off-hours.
advice-to-mgmt: Continue to be transparent about the company/team vision and how individuals fit into that larger plan.

pros: Dynamic, fast-moving company Open, collaborative culture
cons: Need better communication between engineering and other departments/teams

pros: It is a fun and exciting place for anybody to work with all the new and exciting things that they envint.
cons: I would say that the only thing I can say would be a Con working for Google would be if you didn't work for them anymore.

pros: Great benefits. The best team I've ever worked with. Lots of team building opportunities.

advice-to-mgmt: Take better care of you managers.

pros: good work envir, loveit, free food, flexible work hours

pros: good experience, good people, good atmosphere, loved my co-workers, can be fun

pros: I think it is fun and easy

advice-to-mgmt: make sure to give everybody an equal say in the project and not let one person just control over their subordinates

summary: Very small fish in a very big pond

cons: Competition is fierce among peers. Middle-management is hit-or-miss. The pace is grueling and relentless.
advice-to-mgmt: Emphasize management skills for diverse employees. Some employees are motivated by praise, some managers have trouble with this.

pros: Culture has a noticeable focus on being nice to one another, get to work on exciting things
cons: Has gained a bit of bureaucracy around actually shipping software, but not too bad, and most of it is intended to prevent wild, west coding.

pros: Smart people, interesting work, great perks, competitive salary, great place to start your career

pros: Smartest collection of co-workers I've experienced Global scale projects to work on help make the work satisfying Even as it becomes more bureaucratic I always believed they genuinely care about their employees
cons: Your experience may vary depending on team, manager etc. If you are passive about your career growth, it may not match the trajectory you hope for While better at it than most, its simply a very large company with the accompanying bureacracies

pros: Amazing people to work with and learn from.

pros: clean environment nice work space

pros: You can learn a lot from internal materials if you want to. Great culture. Perks, teammates are awesome. You can enjoy free food in lots of cafes.

He didn't trust me and didn't give me fair reviews. He didn't give me enough help either in my work or in my career development. I won't recommend my team to any of my friend.
advice-to-mgmt: They might need to educate managers about how to manage a team and how to give feedbacks to the employees to help them grow.

pros: Great benefits and good pay

pros: Well-paid, fun, everyone is friendly, work as much you want and can do, off site visits, it's Google!

summary: Amazing company, for the huge size
pros: great benefits, fun environment, job stability, working on amazing projects with smart people that impact the whole world
cons: HUGE bureaucracy, with a company this big there is specialized roles and process for everything. Definitely not an "intimate" community and can take forever to get approvals for what seems the smallest thing.
advice-to-mgmt: focus on going back to your roots and staying nimble like before.

pros: Ability to switch between multiple groups. Never gets boring.

pros: challenging but satisfying. Peer review makes you smile at others all the time

pros: So much energy, very rewarding. Google is amazingly open and flexible. Work life balance can be what you want it to be on most teams. (Some teams are in more competitive sectors and require more crazy hours all the time - but very few of them).

pros: Great environment, smart people, leadership is open and upfront, launch and iterate is real and helpful

pros: Amazing work environment to work in

pros: they care about their employees. it's a great place to work. ca might be a better environment, though.

pros: Own Google Corporate credit card, top of the line cell phone, tablet combo,$65 a day food allowance, free monthly rental cars, travel to places ordinarily wouldn't be able to travel to, pay

pros: The people are among the smartest, most driven co-workers. This made it a fantastic experience.

pros: currently think out of none

summary: Great Company, Fast-Paced, They Look After You

cons: The work is tough and you're surrounded by people that are smarter than you, it can be overwhelming but it really brings out the best in you

pros: Awesome perks, I am happy whenever I work on site.

advice-to-mgmt: For this part I think google did great job. All the things are run pretty smoothly and i didn't feel any inconvenient during my internship.

pros: Treated well and as an equal

pros: Awesome perks (meals, snacks, coffee, events), great mentorship, work-life balance point, supportive community, and just an overall great internship experience.
